title: author-sebastian-barry-says-borders-magical-allure
story: Sebastian Barry, the current Laureate for Irish Fiction, is sad to miss Melrose and the ldquomagical allure of the Borders this year.The Costa-winning author of Days Without Endand A Long, Long Way, booked to appear at this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival, has visited Melrose three times, and the area clearly made an indelible mark on him.He said: ldquoIf yoursquore going to be spoiled in this lehellip twice I went [to Melrose] and for mysterious reasons they gave me the Walter Scott Prize [for Historical Fiction] each time."And then another time I was thrilled to go to give the prize to Benjamin Myers.ldquoAll three times not only did I slowly gather a friendship with [festival director] Alistair [Moffat], who was really a great guy, but we were so spoiled, I donrsquot knowwe were fit for human le after that."We had to come back to normal places after that.He continued: ldquoThe Borders held a magical allure for me. You donrsquot just want to go there ndash you need to get back to it.ldquoWhen Irsquom  and trying to think of the signal things that have happened to me as an old critter writer going around, thatrsquoll be high up on the list. Just the welcome of it.Though Barry wonrsquot be able to meet his readers in person this year, he will be talking to an online audience on August  about his latest book, A Thousand Moons.Sequel to rsquos Days Without End, A Thousand Moonsis set in  Tennessee and narrated by native American Winona, who tells of her unorthodox upbringing by two men and her quest for revenge after she endures a brutal attack.Barry spoke to the Border from his home in County Wicklow, on a beautul morning that he predicted with nonchalance would not last.ldquoJust for two hours itrsquos summer ndash itrsquos really beautul, about  degrees, wersquove just had coffee outside, just to feel it.ldquoAnd then it will give way to rain for the rest of eternity, sohellip But in this moment, itrsquos good.Unable to travel to promote A Thousand Moonsor visit the ious book festivals that would normally be on his itinerary, Barry has spent much time in the mountains that look down on his home.He has also been reading books such as Meditationsby Marcus Aurelius ndash works that are ldquostrong winds to stir away the fog of the pandemic.He is sanguine about the impact of lockdown on his book festival plans.ldquoIrsquom a slightly introverted person so doing the festivals does require an effort of mind for me, he said, ldquobut nevertheless now I donrsquot have them, I realise even more how unusual they are.ldquoEspecially for godless folk like myself, itrsquos a kind of reaffirmation of humankind, because you do your reading and yoursquore there talking to your fellow writers, especially at the Borders Book Festival because they have it arranged like that.,params: .pushldquoItrsquos very important for the participants to be among each other as well.He added: ldquoThe aftermath of it is that you have your signing queue. Andyoursquore very old like me ndashyoursquore  ndash you might have some people in the signing queue and thatrsquos a really lovely thing because each person comes up and says oftentimes quite private things to you.ldquoEveryone is on their best behaviour. Yoursquore on your best behaviour! And therersquos just a sort of clemency about it."Therersquos some very deep magic in it and I miss that.But Barry is positive about the book festivalrsquos online efforts to bring its ldquomagic to readers.ldquoDoing it online reaffirms the importance of people gathering to talk about books, to meet the people who make books, to meet the people who read books, he said.ldquoAt a certain level it doesnrsquot sound a lot but actually it turns out to be a huge thing that wersquore now going to have to miss, and itrsquos wonderful the effort thatrsquos being made to perpetuate it.ldquoThis is going to be our effort to sort of be there, like a sympathetic magic, like a group of admirable witches brewing up something that feels like the real thing.To see Sebastian Barry in conversation with Mairi Kidd, Creative Scotlandrsquos Head of Literature, Languages and Publishing, you can click this link.The festival is sponsored by investment management company Baillie Gford.

title: schools-reopening-20-public-buses-taken-pupils
story: PAYING passengers will be banned from  bus services in the Borders as schools .Scottish Borders Councilhas announced that  routes are being deregistered from public use from August , so more room will be available for pupils.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoIt is important to emphasise that while many of the services being closed off to the public may have theoretically been open for public use, the uptake has historically been extremely low, and in some cases unused entirely.To see the full list of routes being taken over for school children only, readers can visit the councilrsquos website.When pupilsto classrooms on Tuesday, five months after the coronavirus pandemic prompted the closure of schools, they will not have to obey social-distancing or wear face coverings. The same will apply to students using school transport.However, pupils will have to use hand sanitiser when they board buses, and the vehicles will be cleaned thoroughly.While unveiling these measures, the council also announced that  public bus services will be taken over for school-use only. The council says the move is designed to ldquomaximise capacity for pupils.Affected routes include the Borders Buses service P from Borders Busesand the Telfords service S .Ms Logan said: "In all instances,any member of the public who would normally use the services still needs to travel and there is no alternative public transport, the council will provide assistance."Anyone in this situation should contact our Passenger Transport team on PLACEtransport@scotborders.gov.uk or call   ."Throughout the rest of this week we will be providing regular updates and information for parents, carers and pupils on all aspects of theto school, all of which can be accessed online at www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolreopening"On buses which will contain both pupils and paying customers, the pupils will be given a dedicated section of the bus. Everyone will have to obey social distancing and wear masks.Services which require pupils to follow government COVID- guidelines include Borders Buses XBorders Buses and Telfords H .

title: m-co-hawick-peebles-stores-saved-closure
story: RETAIL workers at MCo stores in the Borders will keep their jobs, the fashion giant says.MCo is closing  shops across the UK, meaning  people will be made redundant.But the Peebles and Hawick stores will remain open, according to a company spokesman.He said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to confirm that both the Peebles and Hawick stores will remain open following MCorsquos restructuring.MCo appointed an administrator in April after taking a financial hit from coronavirus.The administration process, led by Deloitte, will see the number of stores cut from  to , with around  redundancies from a total workforce of more than ,.MCorsquos chief executive Andy McGeoch said: ldquoIt quickly became clear that the best way to save most jobs and most stores was to enter administration, with a new company acquiring the assets of the old business, and this process has now been finalised.ldquoCOVID has been by far the biggest challenge our family business has faced in almost  years, and I am really pleased that we have been able to maintain a presence in over  communitiesldquoCOVID- means many people donrsquot feel comfortable travelling on public transport or visiting busy city centres and that can be good news for local high street stores like MCo.ldquoThatrsquos why we are looking at ways of working in partnership with other local retailers to highlight the tremendous range of shopping that can be found in communities like this all over the country.ldquoLocal economies rely to a huge degree on their town centres and we have seen too many high streets hollowed out by successive shop closures.ldquoMore and more people are beginning to realise that,they donrsquot support their town centres, everyonersquos quality of living really takes a hit, so we are proud to be playing a part in the drive to shop locally.

title: face-coverings-become-compulsory-enclosed-public-spaces
story: Face coverings will be mandatory in all public enclosed spaces from Monday, the Northern Ireland Executive has agreed.Stormont ministers also decided on Thursday that all children should be back at school by September, but to delay the reopening of wet pubs.First Minister Arlene Foster said decisions at the Executive had been taken mindful of the fact that the R number pertaining to the transmission rate of the coronavirus has risen to an estimated ..vw,vw,px, px"First Minister Arlene Foster addresses the media outside Parliament Buildings at Stormont ldquoBecause of the concern around the level of community transmission and the desire prioritise the reopening of our schools, we have decided that it is prudent to pause the reopening of our public houses and we have set a new indicative date of September , she said.ldquoI want to acknowledge that the hospitality sector have been working very hard with us, they have been in partnership with us right throughout this issue and this is not a reflection on the hospitality sector, rather itrsquos a reflection on the fact that the R rate has risen, there is a rise in community transmission and we always said there is a need to work together to try and push that down.Turning to mandatory face coverings, Mrs Foster said retail workers will not have to wear masks, but those entering shops will.ldquoItrsquos about trying to give confidence to people who feel vulnerable and maybe have been shielding and we are asking the public to work with us and listen to what we are asking them to do, she said.The First Minister also announced a high street task force to help the retail sector, and that theatre and concert halls will be able open on a restricted basis from August , with an indicative date of September  for theof audiences.ldquoWe are going to permit spectators to be present at indoor sporting venues from August  but we have also said that further work is needed to risk assess the reopening of soft play areas and other venues, she added.Education Minister Peter Weir welcomed the ldquostrategic prioritisation given to education.ldquoFor years one to , they will be ing on the basis of protected bubbles of whole classes, and for years  to  try to minimise movement between classes. All the other protective measures that we have put in place and suggested to schools previously remain in place so we are looking after the health and safety of our young people, he said.ldquoFull guidance will be issued to schools next week. The idea is to try and have the maximum level of social distancing, but the overriding issue is to ensure we have full classes.Earlier it emerged that  coronavirus clusters have been identied in the region since May  when the test and trace programme went live, with  clusters remaining open, according to the Public Health Agency .Some  cases of Covid- have been associated with these clusters, with nine of the clusters having had five or more cases associated with them.Earlier this week, two businesses in Newcastle, Co Down, closed temporarily following outbreaks among their staff.The statement from the PHA came on Thursday as the Department of Healthrsquos daily updates showed  more positive cases of coronavirus have been detected in the region, bringing the total to ,.No new deaths were recorded on Thursday, leaving the total in the region at , according to departmental figures.vw,vw,px, px"Dr Gerry Waldron, head of health protection at the PHA, said: ldquoIn the past seven days, five clusters have been identied. Thirty-five cases have been associated with these clusters, with  close contacts.ldquoThis should act as a timely reminder that we must not become complacent ndash coronavirus remains in circulation and we have seen an increase in cases in recent weeks. It is therefore essential that we remember the key advice to help keep ourselves and those around us safe.ldquoMaintain social distancing, wash your hands regularly, and get testedyou display any symptoms of coronavirus.The Department of Health has also said the R number is now ldquohighly likely to be above one in Northern Ireland.The current estimate for the R value is between . and ..R represents the number of iniduals who, on average, will be infected by a person with the virus.A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said while community transmission remains low in Northern Ireland, the number of positive tests per day has increased three-fold from early July.Chief scientic adviser Professor Ian Young said: ldquoThe most recent data for Northern Ireland underlines the need for continued vigilance.ldquoThere are five key steps each of us can take to keep ourselves and others safe ndash rigorously maintain social distancing wash our hands well and often wear face coverings in enclosed spaces where social distancing is dficult co-operate fully with the Test, Trace and Protect programme, and download the Stop Covid NI app..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Face coverings to become compulsory in all enclosed public spaces

title: twitter-introduces-new-labels-government-state-linked-media-accounts
story: Twitter is to begin adding labels to the accounts of government officials and state-affiliated media groups to provide more context on who the account represents.The new feature will initially focus on senior political officials who are the voice of their state abroad and accounts belonging to state-backed media, its editors and senior staff.The social media  said that for political figures, the labels would currently only be applied to accounts from the countries that make up the five permanent members of the UN Security Council ndash China, France, Russia, the UK and the US.Personal accounts of heads of state will not be labelled.vw, px"Example of the new label on Russiarsquos RT Twitter also said that state-financed media organisations with editorial independence, such as the BBC or NPR in the US, would not be labelled under the new scheme.The company said it was an ldquoimportant step which would help users when they see an account discussing geopolitical issues ldquohave context on its national affiliation and are better informed about who they represent.On media organisations, Twitter said: ldquoState-affiliated media is defined as outlets where the state exercises control over editorial content through financial resources, direct or indirect political pressures, and or control over production and distribution.ldquoUnlike independent media, state-affiliated media frequently use their news coverage as a means to advance a political agenda. We believe that people have the right to know when a media account is affiliated directly or indirectly with a state actor." srcset"https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    bab--e--eeb.png w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    bab--e--eeb.png w w, https:content.assets.pressassociation.io    bab--e--eeb.png w w" sizes" vw, px"Example of the new label on Chinarsquos CGTN The  has been one of the most active in taking action against political figures and groups ndash in  it banned state-backed media advertising and all political advertising ndash and has recently taken action against tweets from US President Donald Trump for breaching Twitter rules.Any account given a label under the new programme will be notied and the account owner will be entitled to an appeal, Twitter confirmed.The company said the labelling scheme is likely to be expanded further over time to cover accounts from a wider range of countries.The social media site is to also stop amplying labelled state-affiliated media accounts or their tweets through its ious recommendation features..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Twitter introduces new labels for government and state-linked media accounts

title: youtube-vlogger-ban-cars-melrose-high-street
story: A VISITOR to Melrose has claimed traffic is spoiling the town.YouTube user Edward Burns, , of Glasgow, recently visited Melrose during a walk to the statue of William Wallace at the Bemersyde estate.But during a break, Mr Burns told viewers that he was unable to film at the Market Cross because the sound of passing traffic was too loud."It was just the clamour," Mr Burns said. "Ive been [to Melrose] a few times before, but at the Mercat Cross there were so many cars going past."In his video, Mr Burns suggests that the High Street should be closed off to cars, with the exception of mobility vehicles and delivery vans.He told the Border : "Im not suggesting that the High Street should be completely closed."The number of cars affects the enjoyment you can have."Where the pavements are narrower, you feel you cant stop and look in shop windows - theres not enough space."The Border put this complaint to Melrose and District Community Council.The community councilrsquos chairman William Windram said: "Its not an issue weve had raised."People parking for longer than they should, yes ndash but no one has called for a ban."Parking is a problem."We have other parking but its not close to the High Street."I dont think a parking-free zone will work."A spokesperson from Scottish Borders Council added: "The council is not currently considering any changes of this kind to the road network in Melrose."When the council introduced the current one-way system and townscape improvements to Melrose town centre, a wide range of stakeholders were involved."These improvements aimed to strike a balance between creating a more pedestrian-friendly environment without impacting adversely on the needs of local businesses."Mr Burns says stress can be caused by being around cars.He said: "Lots of cars can create stress."A lot of cars and a lot of people, it can take away from the experience of being somewhere and taking in the things around you."What are your views on this topic Please let us know by sending an email to editorial@bordertelegraph or message our Facebook page at: www.facebook bordertelegraph
